Based on the search results, I can provide comprehensive insights about Robinson Crusoe's colonial themes, Friday's relationship with Crusoe, racism, and modern critical perspectives:

## Colonial Themes and Imperial Ideology

The novel serves as an allegory for European colonialism, with Crusoe representing the European "master" and Friday the "good savage."(no content)Crusoe's actions on the island reflect the colonial mindset of the time, emphasizing domination, exploitation, and cultural superiority.(no content)Upon being shipwrecked, Crusoe immediately claims the island as his own, mirroring the European colonialists' approach to the "New World." He views the island as a resource to exploit, demonstrating a sense of entitlement and ownership typical of colonial attitudes.(no content)Crusoe's view of himself as the "absolute lord and lawgiver" of the island further illustrates the colonial mindset. He regards the island as his personal property, with an "undoubted right of dominion." This reflects the colonial belief in the right to rule over and exploit foreign lands and peoples.

## The Crusoe-Friday Relationship and Racism

The relationship between Crusoe and Friday exemplifies imperialist ideology through Crusoe's treatment of Friday as a possession rather than an equal.(no content)Crusoe assumes superiority, renames Friday, and teaches him to call him "Master," erasing Friday's heritage. He values Friday based on European norms and physical features resembling whiteness, reflecting early 18th-century racism.(no content)It is hugely important that Robinson Crusoe chooses to name his servant "Friday." Robinson ostensibly names him for "the Day I sav'd his Life." Interestingly, he chooses a name from Western culture. People indigenous to the island do not plan their lives according to the same seven-day week schedule used in England. So, even the assigned name reflects Robinson's eagerness to rub English habits and norms off on his servant.(no content)When Crusoe "names" Friday, language and culture intersected, that a new language of racism was born. That Man Friday became the paradigm of the ethnic sidekick, the white male hero's partner of color, who never gets to share in the rewards.

## Modern Critical Perspectives and Social Justice

Contemporary scholarship has significantly reexamined the novel through postcolonial and social justice lenses. The four articles in this special focus issue take up their rereadings of Crusoe in light of 300 years of interpretation, the end of the era of European colonialism, and the advent of postcolonial thought.(no content)Hund recovers an understanding of Crusoe as racist crusader and global capitalist, and articulates Defoe's programme of subtle advocacy in favour of colonial trade. This connects with Hutnyk's argument that reading Defoe from a postcolonial perspective uncovers his satirical strategy of advocacy for trade and against war.(no content)From the point of view of the natives, it's a myth of invasion – Crusoe is a sunburned demon who imposes European belief systems on them. There's no getting beyond the fact that Friday, a man the narrator "saves" from the hands of the cannibals and takes under his wing, is cloyingly subservient to the unkempt foreigner, which upholds a racist ideology of white supremacy.

## Youth Perspectives and Educational Implications

The paradigm I call the Ethnic Sidekick and its concomitant racism have both become an integral part of the New World, its language and its literature, an integral part of the Western perspective and an important, yet invisible, determinant in most multicultural relationships. That this racist paradigm has become institutionalized in the Western democracies, is perpetuated in both "canonized" and popular literature, and in fact, still influences most western thinking and behavior.(no content)As a representation of the "other" in the colonial context, Friday's character offers an opportunity to explore themes of cultural encounter, friendship, and the complexities of power dynamics. Crusoe's paternalistic attitude towards Friday evolves over time, reflecting a deeper understanding of their shared humanity.

The search reveals that modern criticism increasingly views Robinson Crusoe as a foundational text that established problematic colonial and racial paradigms that continue to influence Western culture, making it essential for contemporary readers to approach the work with critical awareness of its historical context and lasting impact on representations of race and colonialism.
